responses.content: We view AI as one of the most profound technologies of our lifetime. We are embedding it across devices and significantly growing investments. We have a hybrid strategy, using on-device processing and Private Cloud Compute. We are reallocating people to focus on AI. We expect to release more personalized Siri features next year.

In the June quarter, we incurred approximately $800 million of tariff-related costs. For the September quarter, we estimate the impact to be about $1.1 billion, assuming current rates/policies. We are optimizing our supply chain and increasing U.S. manufacturing ($500B commitment over 4 years).

Greater China revenue grew 4% sequentially. iPhone acceleration and substantial Mac growth drove this. Subsidies played a role in the first full quarter. iPhone installed base hit a record high in Greater China, and we had the top 3 best-selling models in urban China.

We set a June quarter record for upgraders. The iPhone 16 family grew double-digits compared to the 15 family a year ago. Pull-forward demand in April due to tariff concerns was estimated at about 1 point of the 10 points of growth.

Services revenue hit an all-time record of $27.4 billion, up 13%. Growth was broad-based with double-digit growth in developed and emerging markets. We monitor legal/regulatory issues (like the Google payments case) but don't speculate on outcomes.

For the September quarter, we expect total revenue to grow mid-to-high single digits year-over-year. Services revenue growth is expected to be similar to the June quarter. Gross margin is expected between 46% and 47%, including the $1.1B estimated tariff impact.
Capex is increasing significantly driven by AI investments (Private Cloud Compute, data centers). We have a hybrid model leveraging third-party infrastructure as well.
iPhone channel inventory was reduced during the quarter and ended toward the low end of the targeted range.

questions: Are record upgrade rates driven by product features, tariffs, or AI? What is driving the notable year-to-date growth in CapEx?
Did search trends in April impact the quarter? Are Apple products losing strategic value as search access points?
How would you characterize demand in China? Was the growth driven by subsidies or underlying interest?
What gives you confidence in launching the next-gen Siri next year? Is it tied to investment?
Why would revenue growth decelerate to mid-to-high single digits if Services remains strong at 13%?
How would Apple mitigate if Google payments were not allowed?
Do you see a world where dependence on screen-based devices diminishes due to AI?
How do you think about offsetting the tariff headwind to P&L over time?
Did the Epic case changes impact Services growth? What does the appeals process look like?
How are you thinking about supply chain strategy (China vs. India/SE Asia) given tariff rates?
What drove the above-seasonal strength in iPhone in the June quarter outside of promotions?
Was there pull-in of iPhones in the June quarter? How does channel inventory look?
Do you see LLMs becoming a commodity or core to iOS? Will smartphones remain the choice device?
What underpins the 1% pull-ahead estimate? Was it largely iPhone/US?
Is there anything unique in the December quarter regarding sourcing compared to September?
How much of a benefit was currency this quarter and what is expected for September?
Will CapEx move appreciably higher as you lean into AI?
Is the focus for Vision Pro still on enterprise, or are use cases expanding?
Do you need to accelerate M&A for the AI roadmap?
